text: right good morning everyone I hope everybody got a chance to go see
some of the keynote this morning and hear about some of the very exciting things that AWS is launching in the compute space and data analytics space
and artificial intelligence it's a kind of an overwhelming amount of amount of launches so take a few days to kind of
digest and figure out how you're going to start to apply some of those launches I'm really excited that everybody came
this morning to hear us talk about about higher education and how higher
education is using amazon workspaces so i'm joined with a couple of people on
stage with me today we've got Greg Smith from University of Maryland University College and we've got Piotr Zielinski
who's going to be speaking a little about about George Washington University School of Business
so we really wanted to kind of take some time and it's described a little bit at how higher education is providing
innovative desktop solutions to faculty and staff who need access to applications and information from around
the globe in a very evolving and rapidly changing desktop environment ultimately
you're going to see how these guys are using amazon workspaces to build solutions to meet those needs so
we'll go and have a seat guys and we'll get started here for a few minutes I'm going to give a little bit of an
overview of amazon workspaces to get started with for anybody who doesn't have kind of context on on what we're
doing and then we'll get a chance to hear about the solutions and then after that we'll have a chance to kind of a
discussion with these guys and I'll ask some questions and then have the opportunity for everyone in the audience
to ask some questions
so our goal when we launched amazon workspaces was to provide a desktop environment that was available in the
cloud that felt very fast and fluid and very native and very much the same as
using a regular desktop to the end user who was interacting with that desktop when you launch amazon workspace we're
launching a full virtual machine so you get vast consistent performance over time should always feel like you're
running on a native machine no matter if we've launched one or if you launch 10,000 of those workspaces
we also wanted to make sure that experience was available globally so wherever you are you can get access to
an Amazon workspace that has that performance characteristic so today we support amazon workspaces in seven
regions in the across the globe giving that access globally and that
high-performance globally at the same time we wanted to support you connecting from whatever device type you had at
your disposal so that has meant for us supporting max pcs iOS devices like
iPads Android devices mobile devices also zero client and thin client
solutions and then just a couple of weeks ago we announced support for web browsers so we added support to connect
to your workspace from chrome and from Firefox as with any AWS product the goal with
amazon workspaces is to have it be pay-as-you-go so that is you only pay for what you use while you're using it
so you spin up the number of workspaces you need when you stop eating them you shut them down and you stop paying for
them we wanted that to be at a price point that was very compelling so the amazon workspaces product is available
in a couple of different models there's a monthly billing model and there's an hourly billing model we launched a
couple of months ago now the hourly product starts at a minimum of eight dollars a month when you look at typical
usage and then we scale up from there so designed to really be a cost-effective option for people who need to have a
solution quickly those fees include all of the components
you need for the desktop to work so it includes the running instance itself it
includes all of the storage so the C Drive and the D draw I have the EBS volumes for that it also includes
backups that we do to s3 to ensure that you have your data in case of some sort of disaster and it also includes all of
the streaming so all of the streaming coming out of the workspace is not billed as network traffic
as we launched amazon workspaces it became clear for us that for our desktop to be
useful for IT administrators it had to not require them to make massive changes
in the way that they may administer desktops today so it needed to integrate with their own existing methodology and
tools for administering and launching and maintaining desktops effectively we
needed to have it be a hybrid IT solution so that you could have a hybrid of your on-premises mechanisms for
managing desktops for managing your cloud desktops so to do that we've had a
couple of key integration points first off on identity we support Active
Directory Integration so when you launch an amazon workspace it is just an active directory to main joined instance which
means it shows up and uses all of the existing mechanisms that you have for administering desktops that means for
identity you're using your ad passwords ad username to log into that it also means that all of the tools you have on
premises like SCCM or group policy all just apply directly it's just a standard Windows desktop
in addition to that we wanted to use your existing mechanisms for authentication so if you're using radius
for multi-factor authentication to add an extra layer of security for access we support that as part of amazon
workspaces so you can integrate existing MFA solution just directly into the amazon workspaces environment
now that'll being said what we found is we've worked with partners like like
greg and peter is that everybody has their own mechanisms for doing these things and it's pretty tough to predict
what those are going to actually be in practice so one of the core attributes of this is that we really want to have
customers driving innovation on top of the amazon workspaces so we publish api's that give information and controls
and capabilities to our customers and they can build solutions on top of amazon workspaces so in part of course
it's a fully managed desktop service but in part it's also a set of building blocks that our customers are using to
build solutions inside of their environments so and I think you're going to be pretty impressed when you see what these guys have done with that
capability now that's a little bit of background about amazon workspaces in general but
we've also really begun to dive in deeply with partners who in the education space and we began to learn a
little bit more about what's going on in the education space that is uniquely addressed by amazon workspaces so one of
the top things we see is that there's really a merging of the different categories of student so the difference
between somebody who's a traditional learner in a classroom or in a lab or on campus and somebody who's a remote
learner who's doing online training or is doing online class work is kind of fading away so they've got very similar
needs very similar attributes these days so a broad diversity of
needs across those different environments so at the same time those
students are bringing with them an incredible level of existing IT infrastructure that they owned and
maintained so they all have their own high-speed access from home they've got
Wi-Fi they've got LTE and 4G connectivity from mobile devices frequently they have multiple different
devices that they own they've got phones they've got tablets they've got laptops they've got desktops they've got web
browsers of various kinds and Chromebooks and so there's this huge
opportunity to advance the options for people to get to their workspaces and get to the environments through using
those mechanisms and those things that the students are bringing to the table but at the same time there's some risk
there there's some concern because now you have a broad proliferation of endpoints that you have to support so
the security surface area is exploding a little bit there's a lot of different ways that students can do things that
you don't necessarily want them to do I'm sure these guys have horror stories at various levels and so there's a lot
of risk to be considered there but at the same time you can't have that be a reason not to give them access to the
applications that they need to get their learning done and so you want to have that application that's available in a
desktop be something that they can get to without necessarily exposing yourself to some of that risk
so from the workspaces perspective we feel like we've got a couple of key attributes that really address these
concerns so first off of course is we really wanted to have something that was
mobile by design so we want to have a mechanism for folks to get to their
workspace from any device and I think we've really addressed that we've done that already whether that's in a
particular region in the US or whether that's globally you always have that access and capability
at the same time we wanted to make sure that we can address that need for them to do that from the device of their
choice so we have a sort of bring your own device mentality which is that the
students have the option to use workspaces on their own devices and then that becomes their personal sphere and
where they're interacting and then the workspace becomes the environment where they're really interacting with the
learning environment from a security perspective there's none of the data going on to that local
device there's nothing that's whether that's an intellectual property or whether that's applications they're
completely segmented from that perspective so the local device is not part of that kind of network environment
where all of the assets for universities exist and then of course the real goal
here is to be able to get access to those applications and it's a very nice story for the content developers and for
the universities and educators all of the existing applications you have that run on windows are going to run on the
workspaces environment so now in effect what you've done is you've solved this challenge of how do I take all of my
apps that are desktop enabled and make them available without having to go through some of the heavy lifting
involved in moving to SAS models or having a web-enabled all of that content and so in this world you get to use
those applications that may be real world applications that students can to get hands-on a time with through the
workspace and save some of that challenge and of course at it for those of you didn't see yesterday we announced
support for Windows 10 so now that application set is much broader so Windows 7 and Windows 10 applications
will run fine on top of amazon workspaces alright that's the quick marketing spiel
